awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a 193 nm excimer laser ablation system and optical profiler for in situ (U-Th)/He and U-Pb geochronology and thermochronology at the University of Colorado Boulder
awd_abstract_narration:
The core missions of the CU TRaIL (University of Colorado Boulder - Thermochronology Research and Instrumentation Lab) are to foster innovative, interdisciplinary, and high-caliber research while also providing geochronology data and training to the broader Earth science community. This project will acquire three pieces of instrumentation that will add new high-spatial resolution capabilities to the CU TRaIL. This equipment will diversify the services that the lab offers, expand the opportunities that it provides to visitors, and enrich an array of ongoing research that includes studies of landscape evolution and topographic development, work on lunar rocks to decipher the impact history of the Moon, and investigations in ancient rocks to constrain development of the "Great Unconformity" and links with biologic change. The project includes support for an underrepresented undergraduate summer intern, an undergraduate research seminar, and three undergraduate research projects.

This project will acquire: 1) an excimer laser-ablation system, 2) hardware to build a quadrupole He line dedicated to in situ He analysis, and 3) an optical profiler. The equipment will advance the lab?s research and that of its user community by enabling in situ (U-Th)/He dating, U-Th and He mapping of single crystals, U-Pb dating, and in situ measurements and mapping of other elements. These new capabilities will allow: 1) rapid sample screening for strategic mineral selection, 2) quantification of intracrystalline heterogeneities, 3) direct measurement of diffusion gradients in single crystals, 4) chemical characterization, 5) dating of imperfect and small crystals, 6) largely non-destructive analysis of high-value samples, 7) avoidance of U loss that can occur during conventional whole-crystal heating, 8) more efficient analysis of higher-retentivity phases, 9) possible increased throughput for detrital investigations, and 10) in situ U-Pb and (U-Th)/He double-dating. The project includes support for an underrepresented undergraduate summer intern, an undergraduate research seminar, and three undergraduate research projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview.

The major goal of this project was to establish laser-ablation, in situ (U-Th)/He, U-Pb, and trace element analytical capabilities in the Thermochronology Research and Instrumentation Lab at the University of Colorado Boulder (CU TRaIL). There are three main components that the lab acquired for this purpose: an ESI NWR193 excimer laser system that can provide in situ sampled material to both an ICP-MS and a noble gas analysis line, a KLA Zeta-20 optical profiler for precisely measuring the volumes of laser-ablation pits, and a new, in-house designed and in-house custom-built He analysis apparatus optimized for measuring very small amounts of He.

Intellectual Merit.

All three pieces of equipment have been installed and are operational. The 193 nm excimer laser system was commissioned and has been optimized for acquisition of zircon, hematite, and carbonate U-Pb data by laser-ablation ICP-MS on our existing Agilent 7900 quadrupole machine, as well as for acquisition of U-Th data for in situ (U-Th)/He analyses, with all data being reduced using Iolite software. The optical profiler was installed and commissioned, and is being routinely used to measure the volume of ablated pits, with both the KLA optical profiler software and third-party tools being used to reduce the data. The new He line has been designed, built, and calibrated, with all aspects of the machine (e.g.,valve automation, pressure measurement, mass spectrometer measurements, and data reduction) controlled by custom-coded LabView-based software.

We have used all three pieces of new equipment collectively to reproduce the dates of reference materials accurately. This is accomplished by laser-ablation of pits and measurement of He on our new He line, volume measurement of the ablated pits using the optical profiler, and laser-ablation of pits for U-Th measurements via ICP-MS.

We additionally used a supplement to this grant to develop a custom Sparrow database system for conventional whole-crystal (U-Th)/He data in our lab through a collaboration with the Sparrow administrators at the University of Wisconsin. We are now using Sparrow routinely for all stages of generating and reducing whole-crystal (U-Th)/He data.

Broader Impacts.

The new instrumentation and database capabilities have greatly expanded the range of research questions that the CU TRaIL can address, will be used to help meet the growing demand from Earth scientists throughout the nation for high-quality thermochronology and geochronology data, and have broadened the educational and training capabilities of the lab. So far, the two PIs, three postdocs, one PhD student, and one research assistant have greatly expanded their understanding of LA-ICP-MS and LA-He methods and data reduction thanks to virtual training sessions with application engineers and other staff from ESI, Agilent, and Iolite, a two-day training session by two of us at ESI headquarters, as well as numerous hours of hands-on experimentation and use of the machines. Postdoc Peter Martin worked closely with the designers of the Sparrow database systems and expanded his skills in handling large data sets, and now works as an Earth and Data Scientist at Kobold Metals focused on using machine learning and other scientific computing techniques to increase the ethical supply of battery critical materials.

This project has also supported and helped mentor two underrepresented minority undergraduate interns in the RESESS (Research Experiences in Solid Earth Sciences for Students) program. In 2022, funds from this project were directly used to support one intern. In 2023 another intern used the laser system to generate data for their project. The projects resulted in poster presentations for the 2022 and 2023 Fall AGU meetings.

So far, we have generated data using the laser for at least 8 different research projects, with most data acquired since March 2023. These data have been presented in abstracts, posters, and talks at five different meetings this year. We are seeing a growing number of inquiries from the broader community about our LA-ICPMS services, as well as great interest in our new laser-ablation (U-Th)/He capabilities.
